Dave Skinner wrote:

> ....
>
> 1) should these variables be defined in crawlURI or be part of the 
> Alist or
> even somewhere else?

CrawlURI is the right place.  My preference would be to add the data as 
you've done as explicit data members rather than with anonymous 
puts/gets into AList (We should do some refactoring so its easier 
plugging in different CrawlURI implementations).  Needs to be clean 
division between data that is only to persist across an individual 
CrawlURI processing and data that is to live for the life of the 
CrawlURI (Kris has been talking up this fact with a while now).

>
> 2) if they are in the Alist, should there be centrally defined 
> setter's and
> getter's or should the code just do what needs to be done every time to
> access them?

Not sure what you mean here Dave.  Please expound further.

>
> 3) once upon a time the date variable was the string returned by the
> server.  then it became a Date object. Now its milliseconds because every
> time I needed it, I needed the millisecond value.  Is there a 
> preference to
> what format things like this *should* be kept in?

None.  Whatever is most amenable.

>
> 5) I'm keeping the content-length separate from the *other* content 
> length
> value.  I'm not sure this is required.  By the time there could be a
> conflict the real value should be known.  Can anyone think of a reason to
> keep them separate?  Right now, my preference would be to use the 
> existing
> variable.

The http-header content-length will often disagree with what Heritrix 
calculates as content-length so keeping them separate makes sense.  The 
http-header content-length may not always be present, nor is it 
guaranteed to be correct.

>
> 6) I have no ego attached to the variable names.  If someone thinks
> something else would be better, I'll make the changes.
>
Just a suggestion: I'd add httpHeader prefix to those fields you've 
gotten from http-headers to help better distingush them.

Good stuff Dave,
St.Ack
